abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment reviews
            potential adversity resulting from the implementation of the
            Conservation and Sustainable Use of Biodiversity in the
            Andes Region Project, which included a review of the legal
            framework for, and a consultation process with indigenous
            peoples. Based on lessons learned, that scientific technical
            assistance needs to be based on the recognition, and respect
            of autonomous indigenous decisions, particularly as it
            concerns their traditional methods to conserve, and manage
            biodiversity, the need to ensure adequate, and transparent
            mechanisms for conflict resolution, is imminent. Mitigation
            plans suggest: 1) the development of a continuous process of
            information, training, and evaluation with the indigenous
            groups, farmers, and conservation/scientific groups, to
            protect territorial integrity, and initiate environmental
            education with the agricultural communities; 2) provision of
            training programs to communities, to raise awareness of the
            biological value within their territories, and of associated
            social pressures. Norms for the use of resources shall be
            discussed, and prepared between communities, and local
            authorities alike; 3) in coordination with indigenous
            experts, and scientists, identify the botanical species
            traditionally used for medicinal purposes, to ascertain
            universal medical uses, build logistical support, and
            process information; and, 4) development of knowledge
            exchange programs, as well as promotion of native
            traditional production systems, such as home gardens, to
            build medicinal centers of traditional knowledge to assist
            patients, and, promote marketing of medicinal plants.
